summary.p: Other palaeographic observations. The consonants ka and ra occur in both short and long forms. Anusvāra is usually above the character to which it belongs, but often to the right of that consonant and occasionally atop the next character (the only clear example of this is l22, ṃjalir, but it probably occurs at least a few more times, including the two probable occurrences of the name maṃgi). Dependent i and ī are rarely distinguished and are read as expected where there is no clear indication of either. See also the commentary.

handDesc.handNote: The primary hand inscribing most of the text. Tends to be rather bold, using fairly simple and slightly cursive glyph forms.

I cannot assert definitively that this is a different hand, but line 37 certainly includes a higher number of awkward characters than the rest of the text. In addition, the dependent vowel i may be formed differently here than elsewhere, and most importantly, the consonants b and especially y are drawn rather differently. My impression is that this is a less confident hand, which attempts to draw sophisticated characters with a varying degree of success, unlike the primary hand that simplifies boldly and confidently.

app.note: It is not impossible that the character read as ta is in fact a final T.

I restore on the basis of the Nutulapaṟu grant and London Plates of Maṅgi Yuvarāja, both of which use the same wording, though for Jayasiṁha rather than Kīrtivarman. The characters indicated as tentatively read cannot be confirmed from the vestiges visible in the facsimile, but are nonetheless quite certain.

According to RM's note, ra looks like ru. However, the ū sign is curved upwards. In fact, evidently saṁ was first engraved, then corrected to ra. In addition to this character, there seems to be something added below the line at this point, just to the right of the descender of ra. The strokes visible there are probably not random damage, since the next line bends out of its way below them, so that the string ṇḍalasya in that line is slightly lowered and inclined downward, while the following śrī is at a much higher level. However, no insertion seems to be required either here or in the next line at this point. I cannot read the inserted text, if that is what it is. Its first character may be a small ṇa, and this may be followed by one to three further small characters of whose shape nothing can be discerned in the estampage.

The characters taya are at the lower edge of the binding hole, and are therefore reduced in size and slightly distorted in shape. I cannot fully reconstruct RM's reading and emendation. At the end of line 4, he apparently reads jayaśilati and emends the final vowel to ā. A footnote by his editor completes this emendation to jayāsi-latā. In line 5 it is also clear that RM emends śū to sū, but I fail to understand what he intends with the word praroha, shown in his edition in round parentheses. He probably means this to replace the preceding word he reads as praśūtāya, but if so, then I do not see why he first emends that to prasūtāya. No matter what RM intended, I am confident that the composer's intent was in line with my emendation, based on lines 10-11 of the Koṇeki grant of Viṣṇuvardhana II, which describe Jayasiṁha I as °āneka-samara-saṁghaṭṭa-labdha-vijaya-śīlatā-prasūta-yaśaḥ-prasūtāmoda-gandhādhivāsita-sakala-dig-maṇḍalasya (where -prasūtāmoda- is probably erroneous for -prasūty-āmoda-).

I follow RM in dismissing the second bhuja as superfluous dittography. There is a slight possibility that the first bhuja is in fact a different word beginning with bhu, and thus the second is not redundant. It is also possible that the second bhuja is not simply a product of dittography, but an erroneously engraved word influenced by the first bhuja. The Koṇeki grant of Viṣṇuvardhana II has sakala-lokāśraya-bhuja-yugaḷa-bala-namitāśeṣa- (describing Jayasiṁha), and the composer's intent may have been -bhuja-yuga- here.

I accept RM's reading, which he prints as clear. In fact, the last character of the name is far from clear. If an anusvāra is present, then it seems to be placed in the middle of the circular vowel mark for i. The vowel could equally well be read as ī. Between ma and the putative ṁgi, there is a distinct vertical stroke, as high as a character body. The body of the final character is unclear; reading it as g is possible, but if it was meant to be g, then it has probably been corrected from something else. Possibly, maghiṁ (for maṁghi) was first inscribed; compare line 20 of the Jaḷayūru grant of Viṣṇuvardhana III. Alternatively, this character may have started out as śrī or chrī (for śrīmac-chrī), in which case part of its subscript r may have been incorporated into the vowel i of sarvvān ittham below (another part being the vertical line visible after ma). Yet another alternative is that ge or go was first inscribed.

The ARIE report says the granted village is in canūṟpalli viṣaya. I believe its author must have read the locative ending pallyāṁ like I do even though RM ignores (or his edition omits) what seems to be a rather definite anusvāra at the end. As for the second character, I see no indication of u, much less of ū, in the estampage, but accept the joint testimony of two scholars who have read something of the kind here. The upper part of the third character definitely looks like ḻ, but a damaged ṟ (as read in ARIE) is not out of the question; in addition, the character could be ḫpa.
There are some extra strokes on the left side of pa, which may be remnants of a correction, e.g. from ja to pa.
The lower part of ccha is lost to the edge of the binding hole.

Although RM prints most of this text as clearly legible, the vestiges I can make out in the estampage do not confirm his reading, and though the syntax is garbled, I expect only one name here (see the note to the translation). I cannot definitively exclude RM's reading, but the first character of the sequence that I find illegible does not seem to be śa; the second could perhaps be ma or vā; and the last looks like dra or vra. The first somewhat legible character, for which I provisionally accept RM's gi, may also be dhi, vi or śi.

The vowel markers attached to p and r are short strokes that start out horizontally and then bend upward at a right angle. They are thus different from a regular ā marker, but also different from a plain headmark.

In line 11, the character read as vi could well be ni, possibly bhi, and the one read as sa could be just about anything on the basis of the estampage. The final consonant could also be v instead of n, and no e marker is discernible in the estampage. RM seems to take all of this string as a topnym in the locative, but he does not discuss it at all in his introduction. An editorial footnote interpets this as the camping place, presumably of Maṅgi Yuvarāja, and identifies it as the village Maṇḍūru near the modern village Mopaṟṟu. Given the convincing identification, I accept the reading, but retain a degree of doubt. The second character in line 12 is a complex and strange conjunct that looks most like ñcū. Compare the very differently shaped ṇḍa further on in this line, and the very similar ñca in line 15. It is preceded by a conspicuous dot that I take to be an anusvāra. The following character lacks a cross-stroke, so it may be ḻū rather than ṟū. Moreover, given its flat top, dhū is also possible. Compare dha in line 13 which, though slightly damaged, looks very similar. I see no indication of an e attached to the following r, nor any damage where I would expect one to be.

Though shown by RM as clear and also read so by the ARIE reporter, ṁgi is not really discernible in the estampage. I can accept that what we have here is a damaged g, with an anusvāra above it (rather than before it), and an i marker pushed to the right by the anusvāra on the left, but all of this is rather indistinct. Possible alternative readings include ma.

RM also admits uncertainty reading the end of this word. I can think of no more plausible alternative, but there is no trace of ā, and the last character is very narrow for ya, though it may have a tripartite structure with a vertical stem in the centre.
The ARIE report reads the name as mṟōpaṟṟu. I see no anusvāra here. The subscript part of the first character could be either ḻ or ṟ.

Although the modern village Yellavarru is close on the southeast to modern Moparru, RM's reading cannot be right. I see no way to read the first character as I; it seems to be me, but could also be vo. The second is very clearly a conjunct, but offers no straightforward identification. Its upper part could well be l, while the lower component looks more like ḻ. It is definitely not the usual cursive simplification of subscript l.

The upper part of the third character is indistinct, but looks more like l than ḷ; its subscript part is definitely not ḷ but a simple wavy line for cursive subscript l. In the part I show as illegible, the first character could conceivably be ṟu as read by RM or ṟa, but looks more like ba to me and could be a number of other things. The next character may have the vowel u attached, and the next one after may be ga or ba.

I accept RM's reading, which he prints as clear and without any indication of uninterpretability, on the assumption that these words make sense to him. To me, the characters in the estampage look like kṣocce ḍoḍu.
The space in RM's edition may be indicative of a typo: he may have intended to show the same reading and correction in his edition.
Seems to be a typo in RM.
Since the reading is clear, intelligible and metrically correct, I do not emend. However, this stanza normally has Rāmabhadra here.

div.head: Plates
div.p: Greetings. From the ocean that is the lineage of the Caḷukyas—who were deliberately appointed to kingship by the Divine Lord Mahāsena, who are protected by the band of Mothers, who are of the Mānavya gotra, who are sons of Hāritī, who attained kingship by the grace of Kauśikī’s boon, who perform the Aśvamedha sacrifice, and whose fame has spread as far as the oceans—had arisen a moon who was Kīrtivarman, who earned his great reputation by his political acumen naya, discipline vinaya and valour. His son was His Majesty King mahārāja Viṣṇuvardhana, who perfumed the complete circle of the quarters with pleasant fragrance from the efflorescence of the glory generated by his proclivity for attaining victory in the clash of many a battle. His son, His Majesty the supremely pious Junior Vallabha King yuva-vallabha-mahārāja Maṅgi, whose pair of feet are tinted by the hues of the rays from the gems fitted to the surfaces of the crowns of all the enemy kings bowed down by fear of the power of his arms that were a shelter to the entire world sakala-lokāśraya illuminated by his valour unique in the three worlds, commands all householders kuṭumbin—including foremost the territorial overseers rāṣṭrakūṭa—in Canuḻpalli district viṣaya as follows.

Let it be known to you that on the occasion of the winter solstice we have given the village named Mḻopaṟṟu with exemption from all taxes, the donation being sanctified by a libation of water, to Maṇḍaśarman, who is thoroughly versed in the Vedas and Vedāṅgas and devoted to the six duties, and who is the grandson of Agniśarman, a hiraṇyakeśin of the Vatsa gotra residing in Vanapaṟṟu and the son of giśarmanAlthough the case endings in the text indicate otherwise, I am quite certain that the donee is Maṇḍaśarman, son of ...giśarman and grandson of Agniśarman. According to RM’s commentary, there are three donees: Agniśarman, Suśarman (read by RM where I show a lacuna) and Maṇḍaśarman. This matches the syntax implied by the endings. However, by this reading, only Agniśarman would have a residence, gotra and school; moreover, the next person (the ostensible Suśarman) would be the grandson of Agniśarman with no other family ties specified, while Maṇḍaśarman would (as in my interpretation) be the son of ...giśarman (whose name RM reads as Veṁgiśarman), again with no other family ties specified. It is much more logical in my opinion to assume a single Brahmanical lineage of three generations, with residence, gotra and school recorded only for the grandfather, as commonly done in related grants.—to this Maṇḍaśarman who is devoted to his lord Maṅgi Yuvarāja in astivihasana Maṇḍūṟūra.I cannot interpret this phrase; see the apparatus to line 11.

Its boundaries are as follows. To the east, Mellavaṟṟu. To the south, pulgollipa . To the west, Agūnakṣayyaṁ. Could akṣayya mean a previously granted Brahmanical holding akṣaya-nīvī? To the north, kṟocce dopu. The donated land is situated in between these. Let no-one pose an obstacle to the enjoyment of rights over it. He who does so shall be conjoined with the five great sins. Vyāsa too has said:
Many kings have granted land, and many have preserved it as formerly granted. Whosoever at any time owns the land, the fruit reward accrued of granting it belongs to him at that time.
He who would seize land, whether given by himself or by another, shall be born as a worm in faeces for sixty thousand years.
A seizer of granted land cannot be purified even by donating ten million cows, nor by performing a hundred Aśvamedhas, nor by constructing a thousand tanks.

It is not actual poison that is properly called poison: it is the property of a Brahmin that is said to be poison. Poison kills just the one man, while seizing the property of a Brahmin destroys his progeny.

Hereby I offer my respectful obeisance añjali to all future kings on earth, born in my lineage and in different royal lineages, who with minds averted from sin observe this ruling dharma of mine in its integrity.
What decent man would ever partake again of those donations given by kings in the past to generate merit dharma, wealth artha and fame, which are now comparable to discarded garlands or vomit?

Over and over again, RāmadevaThe name in this stanza is normally Rāmabhadra. begs all these future kings: “Each in your own time, you shall respect this framework of legality that is universally applicable to kings!”
The executor ājñapti in this matter is the masterful īśa magnate dhana-rāśi His Honour Bhānuśakti, beneficient to subjects.
The writer of this decreeThe text ends abruptly here. See the commentary.

The text ends abruptly with the last line on 3r. I agree with RM that only a very small amount of text seems to be lost here, identifying the writer of the text. RM believes a date was also lost here, but I do not find this likely on the basis of parallel grants. It is not clear whether the last bit of text in line 26 is prose or a garbled continuation of the indravajrā hemistich identifying the executor. The intended text may for instance have been something like tac-chāsanasyāsya ca lekha-karttā. No information is available about the verso of plate 3, but it seems most likely that the remaining text was engraved there; it may be so worn that an estampage was not made.

The issuer of these plates was identified in the ARIE report as Jayasiṁha I on the grounds that the seal bears the legend sarvasiddhi and only Kīrtivarman and Viṣṇuvardhana (I) are mentioned as ancestors in the genealogy. RM, however, asserts that maṅgi-yuva-vallabha-mahārāja is clearly the donor (though the published facsimile is not entirely clear, nor is maṁgi-yuvarājaḥ completely certain in line 12; see the apparatus to these lines), and adds that, since Maṅgi Yuvarāja’s seals have the legend vijayasiddhi, the seal may not be the original seal of this grant. He further supposes that reference to the closer ancestry of Maṅgi Yuvarāja were apparently left out by oversight. His editor in EI (probably K. G. Krishnan) adds in a footnote that there may have been a mix up of two different plates at a distant time. Moreover, RM notes that the donor’s epithet is sakala-lokāśraya in line 6, but says only that this means the same as Maṅgi Yuvarāja’s regular epithet sarvalokāśraya. However, the two epithets are not necessarily interchangeable. The question of the issuer needs further study.

Some details to consider are the following.
1, The phraseology of the grant has much in common with known grants of Maṅgi Yuvarāja. However, it has just as much in common with grants of Jayasiṁha I and Viṣṇuvardhana II. Particularly noteworthy is the fact that all grants of Maṅgi known to me begin with a more mature version of the stock text śrīmatāṁ sakala-.
2, The genealogy begins with Kīrtivarman, whereas grants of Maṅgi known to me begin either with Jayasiṁha I or with Kubja Viṣṇuvardhana. Genealogies beginning with Kīrtivarman are found in all grants of Jayasiṁha I that I know, one grant of Viṣṇuvardhana II (of the two I know), and the single known grant of Indra Bhaṭṭāraka.
3, The exhortatory verses are unusual. Stanza 3 does not occur in any Eastern Cālukya grant I know of. Variants of stanza 4 occur (sporadically) only from the time of Vijayāditya I onward (00018), and the first closely related variant is in a grant of Kali Viṣṇuvardhana (00022). Stanza 6 occurs in at least one grant of Pulakeśin II, but among Eastern Cālukya charters, its only occurrence that I know of is in one of Bhīma I (00024).
4, I have not verified this, but the elaborate headmarks of this inscription (usually long horizontal lines with the ends curved up) seem late to me. It may be that a later scribe was attempting to imitate an earlier style of writing. A more detailed study of the palaeography is warranted.

The idea that plates belonging to different grants have been mixed up strikes me as preposterous, since the page breaks concerned would have had to be at the same spot in the text. The idea that Indra Bhaṭṭāraka and Viṣṇuvardhana II were omitted out of oversight is likewise preposterous; moreover, the text progresses smoothly through kīrttivarmmaṇaḥ sūnor … śrī-viṣṇuvarddhana-mahārājasya priya-tanayaḥ … śrī-maṁgi(?)-yuva-vallabha-mahārājaḥ. Any omitted people would have had to have been included in the draft before priya-tanayaḥ, and the syntax would have been quite awkward. Forgery (produced some generations after Maṅgi Yuvarāja and probably using a genuine seal) seems quite likely, but I would expect a forger to have copied a specimen grant with alteration only in the executive section, rather than cobbling the text together from grants of different rulers.

The possibility also remains that it is an idiosyncratic charter of the Maṅgi Yuvarāja we are familiar with. And there is, in addition, some chance that we are dealing here with an unknown Maṅgi Yuvarāja from an earlier time. This person could be either Jayasiṁha I before his formal accession to the throne, or Indra Bhaṭṭāraka. The former did use the epithet sakala-lokāśraya, and if the problematic locus in line 8 correctly reads śrīmachrī instead of śrīmaṁgi, then “the majestic yuvarāja, son of Viṣṇuvardhana” would clearly identify him. The latter, in turn, may well have spent part (perhaps a large part) of his life as yuvarāja under Jayasiṁha I. Although he is not known to have been called sakala-lokāśraya, if his personal name had been Maṅgi and if yuvarāja had stuck to him as a permanent epithet, then that would to some degree explain why his grandson bore the name Maṅgi Yuvarāja as a crowned king.
